abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Fortant de France's 1998 white merlot, available at wine shops in Westchester County, NY; photo (M)

block.p: TAKE the idea of white zinfandel, at best a bimbo of a wine, give it a Ph.D. during wine making in Languedoc, and you've got Fortant de France's sophisticated '98 white merlot.

This warm-weather refresher with a grapefruity, almost-quinine nip -- the stylish equivalent of a sleek Tanqueray gin and tonic -- can be perfect with seafood, as a brunch wine or, under a peppermint-striped tent, as a crowd-pleasing aperitif. A sunlight-refracting salmon-coral in color, in a transparent carafe it could replace a floral centerpiece.
TAKE the idea of white zinfandel, at best a bimbo of a wine, give it a Ph.D. during wine making in Languedoc, and you've got Fortant de France's sophisticated '98 white merlot.

This warm-weather refresher with a grapefruity, almost-quinine nip -- the stylish equivalent of a sleek Tanqueray gin and tonic -- can be perfect with seafood, as a brunch wine or, under a peppermint-striped tent, as a crowd-pleasing aperitif. A sunlight-refracting salmon-coral in color, in a transparent carafe it could replace a floral centerpiece.

The brainchild of the producer Robert Skalli, who almost singlehandedly invented the wine's southern appellation, Vins de Pays d'Oc, this casual bone-dry white merlot is a cornucopia of surprises: a tea-rose bouquet, chiffon weight, fruit-compote complexity with daubs of anise, kitchen-garden herbs, and a piquant and seemingly endless aftertaste.

Icy cold refrigeration numbs the wine, to its detriment, and your money's; drink it cool, and the intricacies unfold (it's even lovely, unorthodoxly, when warm). In the end, it's a bauble -- a serious bauble -- that for some will recall the summer pleasures of a Tavel rose. Don't knock it back: sip it languidly, filling the palate fully.

The bottle costs $7 at Zachys, 16 East Parkway, Scarsdale; $6 in Aries, 128 West Post Road, White Plains; and $6 in Grape Expectations, 92 North Broadway, in Tarrytown. At such prices, the wine is a best buy.
